1.) Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response.



The Total Cray Valley - Beaumont Plant has an RMP Policy to assure adherence to applicable Federal, State and Local rules and regulations. The Plant could affect outside receptors and complies with the OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) Standard 29CFR 1910.119 and thus falls under Program 3 of the RMP compliance requirements.

The Facility's Integrated Contingency Plan (ICP) or Emergency Response program has been developed and outline in standards, procedures, policies and training. The ICP include procedures for notification of local authorities, regulatory agencies and any potentially affected neighbors.





2.) The Stationary Source and Regulated Substance Handled.



The Total Cray Valley - Beaumont Plant produces C5 hydrocarbon resins. These resins have many diverse uses.  The covered processes uses RMP regulated substances above the planning threshold.  These substances are Boron Trifluoride, 1,3-Pentadiene, n-Pentane.



3.) Worst Case Release and Alternate Case Release 



The Worst Case Release Scenarios at this facility would involve either the release of Boron Trifluoride to form a toxic cloud or the release of a flammable liquid forming a vapor cloud that would find an ignition source and produce a vapor cloud explosion.

The Alternative Release Scenarios would involve either a slow release of Boron Trifluoride producing a toxic cloud that would be mitigated with water by a water curtain, deluge system and emergency shutdown systems or the release of a flammable liquid forming a vapor cloud producing a vapor cloud explosion that would be mitigated by emergency shutdown systems and fire monitors applying both water and foam to the cloud and resulting fire.





4.) Chemical Accident Prevention.



This Facility complies with the PSM Standard. Process Hazard Analyses (PHAs) have been conducted on the processes at this Facility. PHAs are also conducted on changes that trigger Management of Chan

ge (MOC) process. The original RMP PHAs are revalidated on minimum of a five year cycle. PSM audits are conducted on a minimum cycle of every three years. 

The Facility and its equipment are designed in accordance with recognized good engineering practices and standards, such as, ANSI, API, NFPA, ASTM and others as applicable. The Plant has extensive redundant systems to ensure safe operations. Operators are trained and qualified to operate the plant. 

Management has placed safety and protecting the environment as the highest priorities for operating the Plant. There is a Safety and Security Specialist onsite and extensive interaction with the Corporate HSSE staff to insure the plant is operated in a safe and environmentally sound manner.





5.) Five Years Accident History.



No accidents  have occured in the last five years involving a regulated substance that could affect any external public or environmental receptors.



6.) Emergency Response Program



The Facility has a well trained Emergency Response Team capable of responding to emergencies. 

The Community is informed about ongoing emergencies via the LEPC, Sheriff's department and/or Southeast Texas Alert Network.
